segments.text: line and we were chipping concrete, firing on bunkers, concrete pail boxes and all that kind of stuff.
And it's a damned expensive way to demolish the enemy's fortresses.
Okay, so you went from Normandy to Leipzig.
You met the Russian forces, and then you went south in Germany to where?
To Pilsen, near Pilsen, to west of Pilsen, and not too far northeast from Nuremberg.
Then we went from there, pushed up from there up to, through the so-called redoubt mountainous country, up to Pilsen.
And when we got to Pilsen,
was already whipped, withdrawing.
Their units were dissolving and the natives were leaving Pilsen in our direction rather than toward the enemy or toward the other way.
streaming along the highway out with the guns in position, pointed at Pilsen and so forth.
So I got in an airplane and made a little reconnaissance over the area, called in and we also picked up some good maps of Pilsen, city maps.
They had one of them laid out in a fire control center and
called in the native and says, can you show us here on this map where the best brewery is?
Make the best brewery.
He put his finger on the spot.
So we put a pin in the map and got the coordinates.
And my last command to the artillery was to draw a thousand meter
no fire circle around these coordinates.
They are the brewery and we expect to be there tomorrow.
That was my time.
You had priorities.
Huh?
You had priorities.
Damn right.
During the Battle of the Bush
Come look over my shoulder a moment.
This thing was compiled by the decor operations in the ETO, 6 January 1942, 9 May 1945.
So this gives the dates and places of...
Where your unit was at all times.
Not only where my unit was, but this is the core, the zone of action.
The whole core.
Now here, from here down to there was the battle to expand and establish the lodgement area.
this thing back to the beach.
Now this is for one corps.
Another corps or two landed over here, and the British were off up here.
So we were the contact corps with the British all the way along here, and now where this narrows down, that's the breakthrough.
As a matter of fact,
General, the general that was killed, what was his name?
Scotch name.
Gee, I'm terrible on names today, isn't that awful?
In the big bombing raid on the breakthrough out of the lodgement area,
This guy was superintendent of the command staff school while I was out.
I was a student there.
It begins with this.
Well, anyway, he was killed there and there's a lot of damn stories about it.
The battle for the breakout narrowed down here and so
The hottest fighting was for this little corridor in here.
About twenty miles south of Normandy?
Well, south of St. Lowe.
St. Lowe was the shoulder that was hard to get past.
Got down to here, and the fighting from here down
was the German.
We had made the breakthrough here for Patton.
A lot of people think Patton made the breakthrough.
Hell, he didn't pull the trigger at the breakthrough.
It sure is interesting though that you spent basically two months just trying to make the breakthrough, getting off out of the Normandy area, and then from August 2nd,
down to September, just about one month, September 11th, you were already on the German border over there.
Well, a lot of things happened there.
Patton didn't come into the lodgement area, into the combat zone.
He was still back here until about D plus
When was, oh about July the 20th, somewhere around there.
I think it was about the time that the attempt was made on Hitler's life, and we had that strange broadcast by Lord Ha Ha that followed that event.
It was just about that time, I'd say about July the 20th.
Now, he came in somewhere around that time, about July the 10th, 11th, 12th maybe.
Now he took command there of the buildup that had been made behind the troops holding the lodgement area.
Then the troops holding the lodgement area
reinforced by recent arrivals, made the big effort and made the breakthrough here.
And you see there's the headquarters of the 5th Corps right there.
It moved from down here on the beach where I talked to Ford, it slipped over to some better quarters near Port d'Ambassade and then followed the
progress of the Corps on down to the breakthrough down here and this breakthrough was a terrific battle.
There could be no mistake about it because the Germans were dug in up to the hilt and it was a rugged battle from this narrow spot here down to here.
Now down here at this stage of the game
The German 7th Army, the 7th Army commander was in command of all the troops in France between, I think his responsibility was about here, and down to this line here.
Northern France.
North, northwestern France.
He had the northwestern
quarter of France.
His zone went way down here below the Brest Peninsula.
I think his command post was some, you can't read the names of the towns on this map, but it's about probably along there.
What about him though?
Well, the commander of the 7th Army was scattered
down here, and at the time of our attack, he was having a staff study.
Where's Rems?
Rems was long about there.
Wouldn't that be it?
down along about there, along this axis into Marist.
But that's where he was, and then what happened?
Well, he was down there having a tactical study.
R-E-N-N-E-S?
Renz.
Yeah, well that's it.
He was down at Renz.
with his Corps commanders and his... and this is before D-Day.
He has them down there in a conference at the time of D-Day.
Well now the commander of the Corps that had the front for
Normandy, all the way from pretty close to the British zone at Foutaques, right across northern France, was a crippled man and an old artilleryman, but still on active duty and pretty sharp.
He knew that the staff
this conference at Renz was to discuss the vulnerable points on his front.
And this thing was going to be a sort of a command post exercise about what would you do if the attack were right now.
That's what
the Army commander is asking.
Now his front, he's got this entire northeastern corner of France, including the Brest Peninsula, are under his command.
So here he is with his staff, his corps commanders, talking about the nitty-gritty.
How's the situation in your area?
How's the situation in your area?
and so forth.
And so this damn almost retired general, he was actually crippled from wounds received here, there, yonder, maybe World War I.
He knew that this was going to be the discussion
So, he says, well, hell, I'm gonna wait and do something before they ask the vital question.
So, what he did is he pinched out, he pulled his, he pulled his most ready division out of their billets
and put him up and told him that his presumption was that his weakest point on the coast was between Grand Comte and Port-en-Bassin.
That included, that was Normandy Beach, including the cliff that
my friend from the nearby town, the former president of the college.
Rudder.
Rudder.
He was to capture that cliff in our plan.
Well, he knew, he knew that his weakest point was from Grand Camp over to some point over here west of
over to the area that was on the English front.
And so he alerted theI think I can give you the number of his division.
He alerted them.
What did you think of when you got into Germany?
What did you think about the German people?
Was there a lot of hatred?
Not particularly.
As a matter of fact, there's an interesting map here and I'll show you if I can find it.
I haven't looked at this in years.
And it was getting down to our sea here.
We're in Germany now.
Yeah, we're in Germany.
So you're running out of targets.
We're running out of targets.
And when the road was clear for our heavy artillery to move forward,
They got to a place called Leipzig.
Mm-hmm.
Leipzig was about to come under our guns.
Mm-hmm.
Now in Eastern Germany.
Yeah.
Mm-hmm.
And the... We had quit
there were any targets that appeared on the front was being ably handled by the light artillery and we were nursing our ammunition and following closely behind them and
I think it was in, we were in Gittington, the university town, the night that Roosevelt was died, and that created a big commotion among the
Well, the messenger came back and says it was, to me, I was to go to Corps Headquarters, which was in advance of my own headquarters, and be at a forenoon staff meeting.
And headquarters was in a place called Nomberg.
and the officer that brought the orders back said I was to be at the Corps staff meeting at Namburg at 8 o'clock or 9 o'clock
Something like that.
And that, well it didn't say what for, but it says for.
What was it for?
Well it was to tell me that they were going to move into Leipzig.
Take a look at this map here.
Here's the corps headquarters at Nomberg and here is the close support battalion of the 102nd Cavalry.
That's the regiment that was on their flank all the time.
And here's the Soviet Army.
Here's the Soviet Army.
And so you were not more than it looks like a mile away from them.
Well back here at this university town, that's where they caught me.
And the fellow that brought the orders back was the civilian control officer.
They called him G5.
He was in charge of relations with the French or whoever the civilians were.
In the area.
Yeah.
And he was a lawyer, still practicing law in Memphis.
he came back and says you're to be at this meeting and says I'm supposed to brief you with certain material here and he says it's highly secret yakety yak and but we're going to capture Leipzig
And as you'll find in this material, Leipzig is in territory that belongs to the Russians.
And he says the big problem is what do you do when you capture a city of 790,000 or close to a million.
I think that is about that figure.
He says it's one thing to liberate.
He says we've been liberating cities in France, but ever since then we've been capturing them.
He says now this is the biggest capture that's gonna be made in Europe.
And he says it's got the old man all worked up about it.
What's he gonna do about it?
And he says

the tentative plan you'll detect in these sheets of super secret stuff and he says you read them tonight and tomorrow have them in your pocket and give them back to me when you attend this staff meeting.
Well,
he still didn't tell me what I was getting into because that was the general's job.
But what it amounted to is that here on this flank was an armored division and on that flank was the sixty
4th Infantry Division, something like that, some high number, kind of Johnny-come-latelys.
And they were on this plank and the 2nd Division, which was one of the landing divisions, was up here.
Now these two infantry divisions were about to put the clamp on this city of Leipzig.
So the old man was worried about what he was, how he was going to come out on it.
So his solution was to use the personnel and equipment of artillery that was back behind him and create a task force to move into the city to grab it ahead of both the
American troops and the German troops grab it, take it and hold it until the military government people had time to send teams up to do the usual job.
They never dreamed they'd capture anything as big as this and they had no teams set up to do it.
So they said, we'll create a task force to go in there and grab this area and police it.
They'll have bulldozers enough to get the rubble out of the streets and to knock over any petty barriers.
And he says,
Where do we get the task force?
He says, well, I'll take two or three or four or six artillery battalion regiments.
He says, like the 190th and so on and so forth.
And he says, we'll create a task force hill.
You see, he's put that label in the city.
And he says, task force hill will be reinforced
by anything that he wants that isn't already lying in the presence of the existing enemy and looking through sights at him.
He says, the city is blossoming with white flags.
It's a surrender job.
But how do we get it?
Because between the time
One army pulls out and the other bar moves in.
There's a completely lawless condition and the civilians kill one another if they've got a bitter enemy that day and there's no authority, no nothing.
So he wanted the old general solution was right on the heels of the second division.

and on the heels of the 64th Division, right on their heels, would be truck-borne personnel and equipment and men to move in and grab the city hall, grab every place, the police station, grab everything, invite the surrender
all the anti-aircraft, my God, the anti-aircraft defenses around this town looked like a hedgehog pointing up.
They'd shot up most of their ammunition though, offered no resistance to us.
And it says, these following Task Force Hill will engulf the city.
and grab everything before there's a reaction.
So that's what you did?
That's what I did.
You moved down and took it.
Now were the people, how did the people react to you?
I know they wanted to surrender, but I mean was there any resistance, any sniping?
Some sniping, very little.
Were they fearful of the Russians?
You're damn right they were.
They wanted you to take the city before the Russians?
to surrender.
Now you can see there was already The Russians are right there, it looks like, a couple of miles away.
Well, on their front at the time I moved in, there was still one battalion, one regiment, another battalion, another battalion.
There were remnants
of those battalions and two divisions up here in the north.
Those two divisions were gonna be contained by the second division as it moved up hot on their heels.
So these two divisions could be written off the books as a threat to a fight for the city.
So we were to go in and act
as a, act as a team.
And they asked me what did I want and so forth.
I hadn't time enough to think the thing through between the time that I was briefed by this Memphis lawyer.
So I had time to think it through and I decided to take not only my own three battalions, I had three battalions, organic then, but I decided to ask for the...
I saw no reason why I should go in there with one regiment.
and I could just as easily have three regiments.
So I said, well, so I had my mind made up.
He says, well, what do you think?

I said, well, I think the 190th could do a pretty good job by themselves, but I don't know why we should be up there clearing the muck out of their damn streets with these other two regiments sitting back here on their fanny.
And I says, I'd like to have
the 166th, and I says, I'd like to have one battalion of engineers complete with equipment for clearing the streets and meeting the disasters here.
What was the condition of the city?
Well, it was shot to hell pretty bad.
And I told him everything I wanted.
I wanted a battalion of engineers and another battalion, I wanted a field battalion, a medical corps, and there's another battalion.
So what I carried, that's Force Hill, let's see.
might be listed in this.
I don't know.
Did you and your men actually bump into the Russians then?
Yeah, there were a few Russians.
For always, you run into a Russian, the minute that the enemy fades from the
When these German divisions, when they found themselves with their back to the river and the Russians on the other side of the river, they began turning in their weapons.
And so stragglers from those people over there naturally began showing up and we immediately grabbed them and put them in a stockade.

We took over the police force in Leipzig, and of course we captured the chief of police, locked him up, put him and his top people in due rest vial, and told the rest of the police, somebody's got to keep some law and order around here, and if
We're going to expect your help and your full cooperation and you're going to help us mop up your city and help you save as much of it as we can.
Now I talked to junior captains.
I talked to the chief of police, but I was too, we had already made the decision
that anybody with a command authority that fell into our hands was not only relieved of his command authority, but was a prisoner of war, period.
And went right back to the prisoner of war center.
What did you think of the Russians when you met them?
Well, I met them in another place.
I met them down in Czechoslovakia and I got on very cordial relations with a lieutenant general commanding the, oddly enough, the 5th Corps Guards.
I don't know what the guards were.
I guess it was
normal Russian division.
But that's another story.
Let's say I've already talked you down for quite a bit.
Maybe we better knock off at one o'clock.
The guys I saw were under very favorable circumstances.
And our first trouble with them, we met them in Czechoslovakia, not at Pilsen, per se, because we, in a rural sort of way, continued to do the same thing in Czechoslovakia that we had done in
in Leipzig, and that is make friendship with the civilian authorities, get their police force out of jail or wherever they were, activate them, extract from them top key men in the city government.
Now, we were always, and this was a handicap, we were under.
These ignorant bastards back in places like Paris thought that they knew everything and they'd write directives to do this and do that.
But when you're on the ground and you're trying to achieve an objective...
It's a lot different.
You better accept the cooperation of anybody that volunteers his cooperation.
the fact that the guy comes in hat in hand and says it's all over.
Now, we disarmed all the top policemen in Lapsing and
If a guy was wearing a weapon bigger than a club, or more dangerous than a club, what the hell are you doing with that?
They took it away from him.
On the spot, the first American that saw him said, I want the weapon.
And the guy would sometimes say, for a souvenir.
says yes, and hand it to me right now, and then pull out the gun and lay it on him.
You can't, in dealing with an armed man, and you're armed, you can't fool with him.
Now, you remained on active duty until February 1946, and at February 1946 you were separated.
You were a colonel at this time, is that right?
Yeah.
And you were, had you given any thought at all to remaining in the service and making a career out of it, or did you want to go back and be a college president again?
I thought of that a lot.
The, uh, in the first place.
Here, have this.
Well, say, that's yours.
No, no, no.
I'm not going to drink it.
You go ahead and drink.
This helps my memory on everything except names.
Names are terrible.
So you had thought about staying in the service?
I never intended to stay in the service a day in my life.
Oh, okay.
So you did not think then, let's get this straight, you did not think?
I did not play with the idea at all.
You wanted to go back and be a college student?
plus the freedom and the enjoyment.
Okay, so you left the service.
Now, the other question I wanted to ask you was when were you promoted to general?
Well... To brigadier general.
You were promoted to major general in the early 1950s.
Well, in the same manner that I never was a first lieutenant.
Oh, in 1946, you were promoted to Major General of the 32nd Division of the Wisconsin National Guard.
Yeah.
Okay.
So you never were promoted to a one-star general.
No.
You just skipped that.
Yeah, just in a cavalier manner.
And the governor then promoted you to the Major General.
No.
The governor had nothing.
Okay, who did?
The...
There's an awful lot of mixed up imagination in people's minds about the, the governor cannot, a governor can appoint any golf of friend he wants to a colonel.
And he can promote him to brigadier general or whatever, whatever he wants to.
But he's not a federally recognized officer, see?
So a promotion without federal recognition.
I was promoted from second lieutenant to captain because
It was to the best interest of the National Guard of Wisconsin, the federally recognized National Guard.
Every unit was federally recognized and every man in it was subject to the active duty militia.
That's what the National Guard is.
Someday when you got nothing else to do, you can read the sorriest book
and the hardest book I ever wrote, and it's the, I think the official title is, we had a hell of a big argument over the title.
You always have an argument with the publisher
I wrote this book lying around here somewhere.
The Texas Navy?
Sea Dogs of the Sixties?
No, I guess thatby the way, my departure from Lou's in 1967pretty good story.
You were appointed a two-star general.
What were your functions?
What were you in charge of?
I was in charge of all of the planning of the training of the division.
It's barracks status and it's home station status.
collectively.
And at camp, of course, we had field training there.
And I was in command then.
And I'm telling you, we could do just about as much.
The only thing that the biggest handicap of the Guard, say, is the Guard a 100% ready organization.
When it comes to knowledge and know-how, they are as 100% ready as anybody in the regulars.
And most of them have at least, are at least graduates of their arms college.
Fort Sill, all that stuff, see.
they have their big handicap is that the personnel, officers and men, are not in a physical condition to go into the field and go into a real hard fight.
Now, the beauty about the training that we had
in which the entire training of the regiment was in my hands.
There was nobody looking over my shoulder telling me what to do.
